awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP:  NSF Frontiers of Experimental Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Principal Investigators Workshop on Materials for the Quantum Revolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstracts are a public record of active and expired awards and are an important source of information on NSF activities. The purpose of the Abstract is to describe the project and justify the expenditure of Federal funds. Abstracts must not contain inappropriate or confidential information, and because they are available to such a wide audience, high standards of quality must be maintained in preparing them.

The NSF award abstract has two parts, which should appear in the following order:

  -Part 1: A nontechnical description of the project, which explains the project's significance and importance. This description also serves as a public justification for NSF funding by articulating how the project serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare; or to secure the national defense. This part of the abstract should describe the fundamental issues the project seeks to address, as well as other potential benefits, such as how the project advances the field, supports education and diversity, or benefits society. This part should be understandable by a broad audience. 

  -Part 2: A technical description of the project that states its goals and scope, the methods and approaches to be used, and its potential contribution. In many cases, the technical project description may be a modified version of the project summary that is submitted with the proposal. However, the technical description should reflect any changes in the project's goals made after the review process.

Upon award of a proposal, the Abstract is available in the Award Search application and via FastLane.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
This workshop brings together researchers to discuss current topics and needs in quantum science and technology which include fundamental aspects of topological phases of matter, quantum sensors and systems, quantum technology and the quantum workforce. The talks are setup to review progress that has been accomplished in the last few years and set out new challenges and exciting opportunities in developing materials and applications for the quantum revolution. Discussions at this meeting are designed to identify key questions within the field and promote brainstorming on future directions. Specific areas to be highlighted include: Fundamental Topics, Quantum Sensors and Systems, Quantum Technology, Quantum Workforce. Furthermore, panel discussions on the current state of research and funding in the ﬁeld of ?materials for the quantum revolution? are planned to elucidate new trends and exciting areas of development.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF CMP PI Workshop: The Quantum Revolution brought together leaders in several areas of the quantum revolution allowing for a broadened knowledge of the field and allowing for collaboration that will further advance research in this area. 

The workshop explored fundamental topics in quantum physics, quantum senors and systems, quantum technology, and the quantum workforce. The broad range of topics covered in the participant talks allowed for robust discussion of future advances and areas of opportunity. The intellectual merit in these discussions is evident in the breadth of knowledge and information shared between specific areas of quantum physics. By sharing advances and developments in each researcher's specific area of expertise, all participants were given a broader scope of understanding of the field of quantum technology and research. Talks on research progress by twenty-four leading researchers in the field as well as moderated discussions of each subtopic covered allowed for the identification of areas of growth, new research, and opportunity to expand the field.

The brainstorming that occurred as a result of the workshop helped to identify key needs of the community, allowing them to be presented to various funding agencies. This generates a larger impact on the physics and science community as a whole as research will continue to explore new areas of quantum physics. The broader impact of such brainstorming and discussion activities is the ability to present a unified understanding of the state of the field to the public. By allowing for the identification of commonalities and dissimilarities between research areas, the ideal way to present findings to both the scientific community and the public can begin to be identified. 

This workshop garnered great success, and held both intellectual merit and broader impact through discussion, research dessimation, and collaborative communication within the quantum community. 

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2018
Modified by: Amir Yacoby
